head.title: A Quiet Solution: Analyze the Crinklers

hedline.hl1: A Quiet Solution: Analyze the Crinklers

abstract.p: Mark Misener letter suggests studying psychology of theater-goers who subject others to wrapper crinkling and other rudeness (S)

block.p: Re ''No Hope of Silencing the Phantom Crinklers of the Opera'' (news article, June 1):

Even more interesting than a study of the physics involved in the noise of crinkling wrappers during theatrical performances would be a psychological study examining the people who subject their neighbors to this rudeness.
Re ''No Hope of Silencing the Phantom Crinklers of the Opera'' (news article, June 1):

Even more interesting than a study of the physics involved in the noise of crinkling wrappers during theatrical performances would be a psychological study examining the people who subject their neighbors to this rudeness.

I expect that such a study would demonstrate that many theatergoers have an extreme lack of self-control and flagrant disregard for the comfort of their fellow audience members, not to mention performers.
The Joyce Theater in Chelsea includes an insert in its Playbill instructing the audience to open candies before the performance and to turn off phones and beepers.
I have noticed a definite paucity of noise during performances there. Perhaps other theaters could also include such an insert.
